top_comment.text:
Is tooth overgrowth common in the wild, or do animals do preemptive filing 
of their own?﻿
top_comment.author: Rinny

comments.text:
They would naturally file each other down, but Jessi has said previously 
that they had to remove one of the four front teeth due to an infection, 
and idk if you noticed, but the only top tooth is reeeeally small. So poor 
thing has to have his bottom teeth filed down.
comments.author: Commander Derpchan

comments.text:
Kemosabe needed to have one of his top incisor removed because of an 
infection. This prevents him from effectively trimming his lower teeth.
comments.author: Jacob Cooperstein

top_comment.text:
When Kemosabe's teeth were shortened, was there pain? In humans we have 
nerve endings within our teeth and I'm wondering if there is something 
similar in a porcupine. If so, do you give any sort of medication to reduce 
his pain? Just curious as it seemed like he may have been hurting as he was 
waking up and if there were cut nerves it could cause a fairly significant 
discomfort for days or even weeks as well as leaving an opening for 
potential infection. However, I'm not educated in the field so I figured 
I'd ask you!

Great show! Saw it linked from SciShow and I've been enjoying your videos a 
lot. Keep it up!﻿
top_comment.author: Stoeterau Fam

comments.text:
+AnimalWonders Montana Thanks for the reply! I really appreciate that you 
took the time to write such a detailed response. You are amazing with 
animals and it's great to see that passion come across. I'm looking forward 
to watching more of your videos!
comments.author: Stoeterau Fam

comments.text:
Rodent teeth are much different than human teeth. They do not contain 
nerves and they are constantly growing. To get an idea you could compare 
them to your fingernails or better, the nails on a dog or cat. The place at 
which Dr. Card chose to trim was well away from the gum line, so it was 
just extra tooth growth and he didn't feel any pain. We try to balance the 
trim between giving him enough tooth length to chew with and also short 
enough that we can wait a full 3 months before having to do it again.

When he wakes up he starts vocalizing because he's most likely disoriented. 
Many animals (including humans) do the same thing even when they are not in 
pain). And if you watch other videos with him in it, you'll see the 
vocalizing is just what Kemosabe does. Once fully awake he does spend some 
time exploring his new shortened teeth and relearning how he's going to 
consume his food. He gets more used to it each time we go through the 
procedure and it's less stressful for him every time. I'm really glad we've 
been able to find a way to keep him healthy that works so well for him.
comments.author: AnimalWonders Montana

comments.text:
+Tim Bowers You can learn more about Kemosabe's teeth in this video we made 
awhile ago, http://youtu.be/cBu2afgqNf4. All rodents have ever growing 
teeth and rub their teeth against one another to keep them in check. Since 
Kemo only has one tooth on top, he can't align them properly to get 
effective wearing on the bottom incisors.
comments.author: AnimalWonders Montana

comments.text:
How would they normally keep them short in the wild? Chewing rocks/hard 
food? I know various rodents will use different things but I know nothing 
about porcupines :)
comments.author: Tim Bowers

top_comment.text: how does this happen in nature﻿

comments.text:
They would naturally file their teeth down against each other, bottom 
against top. Kemosabe only has one top incisor due to an infection in the 
root and we had to remove the entire tooth. He now cannot file his teeth 
normally and the bottom incisors become overgrown.
comments.author: AnimalWonders Montana

comments.text: They would probably chew on trees to keep their teeth short.
comments.author: ibefullofme

top_comment.text: So how do the teeth stay small in the wild?﻿

They rub or grind their teeth to stay in good length, but this one in the

comments.author: CanadianRM4

comments.text:
Kemo's food is already fixed and chopped in nice bite-sizesed pieces so his 
teeth won't wear out as much. In the wild they would eat the food as it 
comes, that being biting into the shell or skin of the fruit of nut or 
whatever, making the teeth wear out faster (I'm pretty sure she'd have a 
better answer.)
comments.author: MaJo Mouse

top_comment.text:
He looks so sweet when he's sleepy! Does he not need his top tooth

top_comment.author: KawaiiCari

comments.text:
+ShadeSlayer1911

Interesting. Thanks for the info. :-)
comments.author: Kemanorel Kin

comments.text:
+Kemanorel Kin According to Jessi in other videos, Kemosabe only has one 
top incisor (his other one rotted out from previous neglect), which makes 
it impossible for him to file down his lower incisors on his own. In the 
wild, a healthy prehensile tail porcupine (and all rodents for that 
matter), will file down their own incisors either by chewing on stuff like 
wood or by rubbing their top and bottom incisors together.
comments.author: ShadeSlayer1911

comments.text:
+Kemanorel Kin
they would go out of their way to chew things to wear them down. Stuff like 
trees, roots, and sometimes rocks and bones (same goes for some birds too). 
When ever you have an animal whose teeth constantly grow it is important to 
provide chew toys for them, not only can it make it difficult for them to 
eat but they could grow into the tops of their mouths or in rare cases 
cause the jaw bone to become misaligned, making it worse! I have rats and 
they have chewed everything I've given them to shreds because they need to 
chew.
comments.author: Todd Koons

comments.text:
+AnimalWonders Montana

How would they file down their teeth in the wild? Or do they just not live 
long enough in the wild for it to matter?
comments.author: Kemanorel Kin

comments.text:
His top tooth is filed down by his two bottom incisors. You can just barely 
see it in the video, it's only about 3cm long.

top_comment.text:
+AnimalWonders Montana 
I used to have a hamster that I'd give wooden blocks to grind down her 
teeth. Do porcupines have something in their natural habitat to do the 
same? Also, are overgrown teeth a common problem among porcupines? (I hope 
not! They don't have amazing veterinarians!)﻿
top_comment.author: Alexandria Perez

comments.text:
I didn't know that Kemosabe had had his top incisor removed. I hope it 
wasn't painful! 
Natural selection seems to be supported by nature endlessly!
Thank you for the response. I'm glad to know that all of these rescued 
animals have amazing care provided for them and hope that you can continue 
to provide for animals in need. :)
comments.author: Alexandria Perez

comments.text:
Porcupines in the wild would chew on many different natural items in their 
habitat. They would keep their teeth short enough by wearing them against 
one another. If they didn't keep them trimmed, they would eventually either 
die of starvation or infection from the long teeth causing wounds in their 
mouth.

It's not uncommon for any rodent to have problems with their teeth. If 
their teeth don't wear evenly, they usually don't survive long and their 
genes will not be well represented in the next generation.

Kemosabe only has one tooth on top due to an infected top incisor that 
needed to be removed. He no longer can wear his teeth down evenly. This is 
why he needs routine teeth trims.
comments.author: AnimalWonders Montana

top_comment.text:
a bit of an unimportant question, but i was wondering why you let Kemosabe 
wake up in the crate and then put him back in his "home" instead of just 
putting him in his home and let him wake up there? not sure if that made 
sense, but oh well.﻿
top_comment.author: Mar

comments.text: Thank you for answering!
comments.author: Mar

comments.text:
Great question! We didn't explain that in the video. If we let Kemosabe 
wake up in his home he would immediately try and climb up his tree before 
he was coordinated enough for it to be safe and successful. Meaning, he 
would fall off and hurt himself. We keep him in his crate until he's awake 
enough to climb safely.
comments.author: AnimalWonders Montana

comments.author: Pile of carbon

comments.text:
This reminds me of when I got an eye surgery at 8 years old. When they 
wanted to put me under they got out this huge needle. I was terrified and 
screamed that I didn't want the surgery after all.

But, they held me down and injected the stuff in me, and a few seconds 
later I went from screaming and writhing to black-out in the blink of an 
eye. Just like that.

Granted, not all sedatives work like that, but I think it's an interesting 
anecdote.
comments.author: OwariNeko

comments.text: +Paul Tee That'd be a weird scene :D
comments.author: 1234kalmar

comments.text:
Depending on the sedative and the dose of course, it shouldn't be harmful. 
Although I doubt you'll get your local vet to give you one. :D

top_comment.text:
I just realized that you must spend tons on vet bills! Do the animals have 
insurance?How do you get health insurance for such exotic animals? For that 
matter, how do you find a vet than knows how to deal with such exotic 
animals?﻿
top_comment.author: sutematsu

comments.text:
Ahhhh.   Ya makes sense.  Sorry I misunderstood.  I was overly wordy 
because I wasn't sure if you're from the US and/or familiar with all that 
junk  My apologies.
comments.author: watts300

comments.text:
+watts300 I know that in the USA health insurance is alive and well. I too 
pay a hefty amount (over $2000 a year) for mine. I was simply saying that 
it is a great thing that some countries can take care of animals without 
worrying about where the money will come from. With such approach to health 
and money soon we will eliminate all wildlife and human lives here in the 
USA
comments.author: tissa71

comments.text:
+tissa71 Health insurance is alive and well for people here in the USA. I 
pay a monthly premium (taken out of every bi-weekly paycheck I receive) 
through my employer.  Many people, such as myself, prefer this to 
socialized healthcare like what you described.  There are some insurance 
companies that even offer insurance for pets, but I don't know if those 
companies (or different ones) offer plans for animal sanctuaries/rescues 
like Animal Wonders.  However, non-profit organizations in the USA have the 
potential to receive different treatment from various parties.  For 
example, monetary donations are tax-deductible from income taxes.  It's 
considered a "perk" of sorts for the donator.  Furthermore, a doctor (even 
veterinary) could potentially offer his/her services in the same manner; 
since the services have a dollar value, the service performed could be 
income-tax-deductible.   I suppose my thoughts were more specific than what 
I had asked:  if the regular visits and treatments to Animal Wonders are 
discounted in one way or another.
comments.author: watts300

comments.text:
luckily in many countries there is no such thing as insurances for health. 
It comes and is funded directly from taxes that citizens pay. I assume this 
is USA tho. they probably have donors and volunteers who donate money
comments.author: tissa71

comments.text:
I wonder if the doctor(s) offer reduced rates for establishments like

captions.text:
JESSI: Hey guys, today we have a really special
person here. This is Dr. Card and, um, she

comes and takes care of all of our animals
for us. Um, she is here to help Kemosabe today

because his teeth are way too long and so
she's going to come and help trim off his
teeth. Thank you, Dr. Card
[Both laugh]

DR. CARD: It's always fun to come and see
all the different animals.
JESSI: Yeah, we have a - a nice collection.

JESSI: Hey bud, oh, I know, I'm sorry, I woke
you up. Come on down. I know. I know.

So the best procedure that we found with Kemosabe
is that we're gonna go and get him calmly

into his crate, um, and then Dr. Card is going
to inject him with an immobilizer and, uh,

a sedative so that we can safely and, uh,
easily dremel his teeth down.

So right now you're seeing us - we're going
to put him in the crate, and we're lifting

the crate up so we can get his thigh close
enough to the side so we can get an easy access

to his muscle, and we're going to give him
his injection.
Nice work. We're gonna set you down.

And now we're going to cover him up so that
he gets nice and drowsy in a calm fashion,

and he's going to just relax into that sedative
and immobilizer, and he won't fight through

it. Sometimes, if they get too riled up, their
adrenaline can actually overpower the medication,

so we're just gonna keep him nice and comfortable
under a towel.

We're looking at Ash the chinchilla now, and
Ash has been having some struggles with some

respiratory infections and some eye infections
as well, and we've been taking him into the

vet and found that he has had overgrown molars.
His top left molars are overgrowing, so we've

been working with Dr. Card to try and figure
out how we're going to, um, manage Ash's condition.
DR. CARD: He's way better than he was.
JESSI: So do you think we got ahead of it?
DR. CARD: I think so.

JESSI: Do you think we'll need to go in for
another exam - I mean, should we - should
we do it preemptively?
DR. CARD: We should.

JESSI: Okay. Alright, so let's schedule an
appointment and just see where it's at.
DR. CARD: Yeah.

JESSI: When do you think he'll be ready to
do shows again? We haven't done anything with
him.
DR. CARD: Let's take a look in his mouth.
JESSI: Okay.
DR. CARD: And then -
JESSI: And see.
DR. CARD: And see.
JESSI: Okay.
DR. CARD: Yeah.

JESSI: And then I want you to look at Pearl's
- there's a baton under this towel, just so
you know.

DR. CARD: Oh, thank you. [Both laugh.] Oh,
that's fantastic.
JESSI: Her tongue is so crooked.

DR. CARD: Yeah, well...it may always be like
that. But that looks great.

She had an infection, um, in her mouth, actually
in the bone of her jaw. Um, it started out

over on this side - it was right in here - then
it moved over to this side and, um, was just

a nasty osteomyelitis in her jaw, which - there's
no evidence of it at the moment, which is
good. Yeah.

JESSI: Good girl, Pearl. And can you check
Joy's beak?
DR. CARD: Yeah.

JESSI: It's really long, but I want to see
if it's too long. We were concerned that Joy's

beak was too over-grown, so we asked Dr. Card
her opinion, and she agreed that it's grown

too much. And so she wants to file it down
just so it doesn't grow too far.

The problems with that are going to be difficulty
eating, and then also it can grow all the

way down into the neck and that would obviously
be a bad thing.

Want to go down on the floor? I have a towel
just for you.

So the way that we're going to restrain Joy,
we're not going to use any kind of immobilizer

or anything like we did on Kemosabe. Instead,
we're just going to use a towel, and that's

gonna help cover her body and restrain her
wings, and then we're gonna restrain her cheeks

so that she can't bite herself, the towel
or us.
DR. CARD: Okay. She did do really good.
JESSI: Good girl.

DR. CARD: Are you ready? Are you a sleepy
bear?

JESSI: All right. Kemosabe is nice and sedated
right now and, um, he's breathing good - we

gave him the proper amount of sedative and
immobilizer and he's doing great. We're gonna

lift him up onto this table and now we're
going to examine his teeth and see how much

growth that they have accumulated in the last
three months.

So you can see Dr. Card is now - she's filing
down - she's using a dremel. She's going to

find the placement where she's going to dremel
the teeth so that they're short enough, but

not too short. And so you can see some of
the dust from his teeth going up in the air.

And now we're done, and we're gonna trim his
nails just to make sure they're all - they're
all at the right size.

Now he's gonna go back in his crate and he's
going to just relax in there until the medications

wear off and then he'll slowly wake up and
we'll let him go back home.
DR. CARD: Hear him complaining in there?

JESSI: [Laughs] A little bit. He's already
starting to wake up a little bit.

DR. CARD: Yeah? Don't mash your nose. There
you go, bud.

JESSI: You're all cozy in there, right? All
right. Sleep tight, buddy. See you in a couple
hours.

Well, thank you so much for coming and helping
out and, um, we'll see you in three months

again - or Kemo will see you in three months
again.
DR. CARD: Okay.
JESSI: Thank you.
DR. CARD: It went really great today.

JESSI: It did. Oh, I'm so happy. Thanks. Thanks,
guys.
